prompt.preamble: We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences. In this activity, we're going to be looking at different strings of text and you'll be deciding if they look like they could be an email address or not. For example, most people would agree that "username@domain.com" looks like an email address, while "n12z5lFEN4" does not. However, the rules for what can be an email address can be very unusual, so what we're really interested in is your intuition on what an email address could look like. Tip: in an email such as username@cs.stanford.edu, "username" is called the local-part of the email, while "cs.stanford.edu" is the domain. Furthermore, "cs" is a subdomain, and "edu" is a top-level domain.
prompt.task_description: your intuition of what is or is not possible for an email address
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of email addresses, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your email preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following strings look like reasonably well-formatted email addresses or not: "yes" if they do, "no" if they don't.

conversation_history.message: Should the regex also validate the domain part of the email address, ensuring it contains at least one period and no invalid characters?
yes
Should the regex enforce that the email address starts with a letter or a number, and not a special character or underscore?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with subdomains (e.g., john.doe@subdomain.domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with multiple periods in the local part (e.g., john.doe.part2@domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with hyphens or plus signs in the local part (e.g., john-doe+part2@domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with special characters (e.g., %, $, &, *, etc.) in the local part (e.g., john%doe@domain.com)?
probably not
Should the regex allow for email addresses with uppercase letters in both the local part and the domain part (e.g., John.Doe@Domain.com)?
i don't think it matters cause gmais are case insensitive
Should the regex allow for email addresses with numbers in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain123.com)?
for sure
Should the regex allow for email addresses with underscores in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain_part.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with country-specific or other non-standard top-level domains (e.g., john.doe@domain.co.uk or john.doe@domain.xyz)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with multiple consecutive periods in the local part (e.g., john..doe@domain.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with multiple consecutive periods in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain..com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a period immediately before the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe.@domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a period immediately after the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe@.domain.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a period at the end of the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain.com.)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a hyphen in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain-part.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a hyphen immediately after the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe@-domain.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a plus sign immediately before the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe+@domain.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a plus sign in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain+part.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a single character in the local part (e.g., a@domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a single character in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@a.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a digit immediately after the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe@1domain.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a digit immediately before the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe1@domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a period immediately after the hyphen in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain-.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a hyphen immediately before the @ symbol (e.g., john.doe-@domain.com)?
no
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a digit as the first character in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@1domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a digit as the first character in the local part (e.g., 1john.doe@domain.com)?
yes
Should the regex allow for email addresses with a period immediately before the hyphen in the domain part (e.g., john.doe@domain.-com)?
no

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to collaboratively help someone design a regex that will validate that an email address adheres to a specific format (e.g. for developing a Python regex).

Previous questions:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative yes/no question that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Make sure your question addresses different aspects of the regex than the questions that have already been asked. At the same time however, the question should be bite-sized, and not ask for too much at once. Generate the yes/no question and nothing else:
